The treatise says:

Because it is born from extensive goodness, it is called Brahma. This Brahma is great, so it is called Great Brahma.

Because the abodes of the gods in the lower heavens in space are like clouds densely covering, it is called Cloud.

These seventeen places, along with the world of the vessels and all sentient beings, are collectively called the form realm.
Some others explain the name of the seventeen places differently, establishing two places in the first trance state in general, and calling the fourth trance state the non-conceptual state.
That teacher should say that there are eighteen places, because the great Brahma, compared to the Brahma assistants, has a different life span, body size, and feeling without investigation, etc.

This objection is unreasonable, because the birth of the non-conceptual state is bound to the fruit of karma of the heaven of vast fruit.

This example is not correct, because the great brahma god is one.

Although life, etc., are different from the others, still, because one body does not constitute a commonality of karma, it is combined with the heaven of brahmaâ€™s assistants to establish one heaven. The cultivation of the various meditations is divided into three grades, superior, middling, and inferior.

Therefore, the establishment of the various heavens of the realm of form is only the unconfused explanation of our National Teacher.
The differences in location of the realm of form have already been explained.

There is absolutely no location in the formless realm, because formless dharmas have no location. Past, future, non-indicative form, and formless states do not abide in locations, because this principle is certain.
However, there are said to be four kinds due to differences in superiority and inferiority of the results of retribution.

The first is the sphere of infinite space, the second is the sphere of infinite consciousness, the third is the sphere of nothingness, and the fourth is the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. These four kinds are called the formless realm.
These four are not distinguished by higher and lower realms, but only by birth, there are differences in superiority and inferiority.
How do we know that they have no location?
It is because those who attain concentration in a certain place, when their life ends, are born in that same place.
And when they die and are reborn in the desire or form realms, the intermediate existence arises in that same place.
Although the four kinds are different due to birth, there is no distinction of higher and lower realms.
What is the reason for the sequence of the four?
It is because one gradually becomes free from desire and gradually attains concentration.
Or it is precisely because the sequence of birth is like this, due to the power of the cause of birth, the effect is more or less.
Just as in the form realm, all sentient beings must rely on form for the continuity of mind and body,
what do sentient beings who are born in the formless realm rely on for the continuity of mind, etc.?
Why does doubt arise here again?
Because in all dharmas there is no self. The mind and mental factors in the desire and form realms can continue to evolve in dependence on the material body.
In the formless realm, since there is no form, mind, etc., there should be no meaning of continuous evolution. Therefore, doubt arises here now.

One should know that they continue in dependence on homogeneity and life, not on a self as support. The word etc. includes other non-associated formative forces, such as acquisition, non-acquisition, and birth, etc.
It is not that in this [passage] homogeneity, etc. are shown to have real substance, because that has already been established.
It only shows their function, which is to be conditions. Conditions means to be a support, causing the mind, etc. to continue.

The four consciousnesses of the eye, etc. each use the immediately past mind and its own material faculty as its support and as its nature of support. The great elements that are the support of its own material faculty, the body faculty and the great elements, homogeneity, life faculty, acquisition, etc., and birth, etc. are only the nature of support.

The body consciousness uses the mind and the body faculty as its support and as its nature of support. It only uses the great elements that are the support of the body faculty, the homogeneous character, the life faculty, acquisition, etc., and arising, etc., as its nature of support, not as its support.

The mental consciousness only uses the immediately past mind as its support and as its nature of support. The body faculty, the great elements, the homogeneous character, the life faculty, acquisition, etc., and arising, etc., are only its nature of support.
In this way, the minds, etc., of sentient beings in the desire and form realms continue in existence supported by form, the homogeneous character, the life faculty, etc.

Since sentient beings in the formless realms are without form, their minds, etc., continue in existence supported only by the homogeneous character and the life faculty, etc. It is not the case that they are without a support.
What is the difference between the two characteristics of support and supported?
Now, examining the purport, the difference between the two characteristics is that this must be born when that exists, and is not born when that does not exist. This is the characteristic of support.
That which definitely has that characteristic and changes in accordance with it is called the supported and the characteristic of the supported.

How can you say that the aggregates of form, etc., are the support of mind and its activities, since sometimes mind and its activities are not continuous, even though the homogeneous character of form, etc., exists?
This criticism is not reasonable, because there is another factor that can oppose mind and its activities and prevent their continuity.
When mind and its activities are continuous, they must have that as a support, and therefore it is the characteristic of the support of mind and its activities.
We see that mind and its activities are definitely not born in a dead body, and mind and its activities are definitely born in a living body. Therefore the support of form, etc., is well established.

Consequently, we know that form, sound, etc., cannot be the support of mind and its activities, because even though form, sound, etc., exist in external things, mind and its activities never evolve with respect to them. The characteristic of support is not universal, because not all mind and its activities evolve in accordance with the support.
Mind and its activities do not definitely evolve in accordance with the immediately past mind and its activities, so how can you say that the immediately past mind and its activities are its support?
Mind and its activities definitely evolve in accordance with the organ of manas.
As for â€œfollowing the transformation,â€ it means causing change.
The immediately past mind, at the moment of cessation, causes the subsequent mind, etc., to enter the state of arising.
The mind faculty has already ceased, and the mind, etc., have already arisen. In this way, the subsequent [mind, etc.] is transformed by the preceding [mind faculty].

The non-homogenous mind, etc., are not the support of the mind, etc., like the eye faculty, etc. The immediately past mind is the support of the mind, etc., therefore the characteristics of the supported and the characteristics of the support are different. It pervades all the supported without the fault of confusion.

In this way, the minds of all sentient beings in the desire and form realms, which arise together with the four aggregates, are all the nature of the support. Only one form aggregate can be the supported.
The support of mental consciousness should also include form, because it changes when form changes. It is presently seen that when the great elements such as alcohol disturb the mind, it changes.

It is not possible for mental consciousness to have form as its support. The support must definitely be able to produce change. Mental consciousness is not definitely produced by the change of the great elements, because even when the great elements do not exist, it still exists.
Therefore, the great elements, in relation to mental consciousness, can only be the support and not the supported.
Therefore the six consciousnesses in the realm of desire and the realm of form have as their innate support the four aggregates.
In the formless realm, mental consciousness has no material form as support, and its innate support is only the three aggregates.
If this is so, why does the Abhidharmasamuccaya say that the formless mind, etc., have as support the similarity of species and the vital faculty?
This is said because they are definitely the same and unconfused support.
Although mind and its activities are mutual supports, they are not definitely the same, because they do not support themselves.
Nor are they unconfused, because in this stage of birth, confused minds and mental activities of self and others are produced.

The similarity of species and the vital faculty are the same support for mind, etc., and because they are only born in this stage, even though they may produce minds of other stages, they are still called born in this stage.
They are called born in this stage because they are attracted by karma and are born in a continuous series. Therefore they are said to be the same and unconfused support.
Mind, etc., are not like this, and for that reason they are not mentioned.

If these two were not so, then when the four aggregates of other stages are present, sentient beings would be called beings of other stages, not of this stage, because the results of actions of previous lives of this stage would not continue.

But this cannot be accepted. Therefore you should understand that just as the homogeneous character and life of the realm of desire and the realm of form are the supports of mind, etc., even though sometimes minds of other stages arise, still the body, etc., in this life will definitely attract the arising of a mind of this stage.

In the same way, even though there is no body in the formless realm, the mind, etc., definitely rely on the homogeneous character and life. Therefore the verse speaks only of the homogeneous character and life.

This is because it is the result of the maturation of projecting karma and is the cause of the continuation of the results of other karmas, just as a tree trunk, etc., exist in dependence on the roots.

We see that even though the leaves, branches, and trunk of a tree are born from the same seed, still they exist in dependence on the roots. Therefore you should not say that the eye and other organs exist only in dependence on the results of action and have no other support.
Therefore, the treatise does not say that the mind and so on that are born in the formless realm must have a separate support.

The evolving mind uses associated dharmas as its support. Because of this, the treatise mentions acquisition and so on in general terms and does not mention them by name. This is because they are not only born of action.
Even if they are born of action, they are not continuous. How can they be the support of mind and so on?
This is because if they do not exist, the mind and so on of that realm will definitely not be born, just as in the absence of a body.
Or, they are the cause of nonconfusion. Therefore, when one is born in a higher realm, the good of the lower realm is not accomplished.
Also, one does not accomplish the nature of an ordinary person of a different realm.
Therefore, it is completely established that they are the support of mind and so on.
Other masters say:
Just as a flame does not arise in a pit or trench without wind,

Or, there are disciples who make this inquiry:

The aggregates of form and so on are the support of the mind and mental activities, because they are the support of the mind and mental activities in the formless realm. The same is true of the nonassociated formative forces, which are also able to be the support of the mind and mental activities, because they are able to generate consciousness, etc. Therefore it is said that the nonassociated forces are the support of the mind, etc., but the four aggregates that are born with the nonmaterial forces in the formless realm do not have the meaning of being a support.
However, in this discussion, the mind is the support of feeling, etc., but feeling, etc., are not the support of the mind, because they are not its objects.

When the mind generally cognizes the characteristics of an object, only then can feeling, etc., grasp its specific characteristics. Therefore they are associated with the mind, but the mind is not associated with them.
However, the mind and mental activities are called mutual supports and are said to be associated because they have the same result.
Why is it not said that in the realm of desire and the realm of form, these two are the support of the mind, etc., and that the continuity of the mind, etc., is based on the body?

Although the homogeneous character of the body in the realm of desire and the realm of form is always a support, it is able to be a support, but the body is gross and obvious, and for that reason it is mentioned in particular.

Or, it is said in order to establish that the homogeneous character and the life faculty exist apart from the body. It is not because the karmic result, mind, etc., are always present in the formless realm or other realms.
Or, it is said in order to show that the homogeneous character, the life faculty, etc., also evolve in dependence on the body.
Even though they and the body are mutually dependent, the body is superior and is therefore said to be their support.

Even though they do not evolve if the life faculty is absent, the body often encounters calamities, etc., and the life faculty, etc., are also damaged or benefited along with the body. Therefore the body is the superior support for them.
Because of this, the Abhidharma masters say that in the formless realms, the homogeneous character and the life faculty, etc., are mutually supportive because there is no body.

The Sthavira says that in the formless realm, mind and mental activities support each other, like two bundles of reeds supporting each other, or like name-and-form support each other in the lower realms.

Even though in the realm of desire and the realm of form, the four aggregates are called name-and-form and support each other, still it is admitted that they are supported by form.
In the same way, even though mental activities support mind in the formless realm, still it must be admitted that they are supported by something else and are able to continue in a series.

In reality, it should be so, but it is said that the majority of latent afflictions are distinguished, because sentient beings mostly manifest the latent afflictions of craving.
As for craving for desire, it refers to craving in the desire realm, and it is the same for craving in the form and formless realms.
In brief, it is said that craving for food and craving for sexual activity can be established as desire, as stated in a verse in the sutra:
The wonderful objects in the world are not true desire, true desire is the craving and discrimination of people.
Wonderful objects remain in the world as they are, the wise have already eliminated desire for them.
This verse is spoken to show that craving and desire have the same essence under different names.

The realm belonging to desire is called the desire realm, the realm belonging to form is called the form realm, the middle word is omitted when speaking like this, just as pepper drink and diamond ring.
In that realm, form does not exist, so it is called the formless realm.
What is called form has the meaning of change and obstruction, or the meaning of manifestation.
The substance of the formless realm is not form, and it is given the name formless because it is devoid of form. It is not that it is devoid of form only in the sense that form does not exist there.
The realm to which the formless realm belongs is called the formless realm, omitting the middle term, as in the previous analogy.
Also, the realm of desire is called the desire realm because this realm is able to support desire. The form realm and formless realm should be understood in the same way.
If a realm has form but lacks concentration, it is called the desire realm;
if a realm has form and also has concentration, it is called the form realm;
if a realm is formless but has concentration, it is the formless realm.
Or, a realm in which there is form and objects of desire is called the desire realm;
